How many stories of violence, racism, abuse of power and suicide will it take to convince this minister to take this Senate report seriously and to fix this broken system of military justice?

—Bad cases do not make good law and I am sorry to hear the honourable senator having a go at the ADF in this way. In most instances, the military justice system has worked well. Where it has not done so, what can be learned from the experience should be learned. If reform is necessary in structure, policy, implementation or resources then such changes should be made. That is what I was saying on Sunday. I do take that report very seriously. It was, in this instance, a bipartisan report. A great deal of effort was put into it. I have already instructed that the response to be developed as an advice to me from my department has to be done promptly. I have said that I am looking for a response expeditiously in this instance because I do think the issues are very serious. Where change is warranted, change will be effected. (Time expired)

—Order! I would like to draw the honourable senators’ attention to the presence in my gallery of a group of Australian defence personnel. The personnel represent the 1st Combat Engineer Regiment based in the Northern Territory. Together with other Army colleagues and personnel from the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force, they were honoured today in the Great Hall for their contribution to the Indonesian tsunami and subsequent earthquake. I know I speak for all senators in saying that you all made us so proud in undertaking such a difficult humanitarian exercise in the best traditions of the ADF.

—My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Today is, of course, World Refugee Day. In that light I ask the minister to provide an update of the government’s ongoing commitment to providing resettlement solutions for refugees and others in desperate humanitarian need.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Knowles for her question. Today is indeed World Refugee Day and the government remains as committed as it ever has been to an orderly resettlement program that provides protection to those who need it most. These are the people who are in UNHCR camps, some of whose kids have lived all their lives in places without running water and without power. These, by any definition, are the people most in need.

answer.para: In 2005-06 our bipartisan humanitarian program will again offer new life and new hope to about 13,000 people who come to Australia from offshore and through the front door. That program includes 6,000 refugees, which is an increase of 50 per cent from 4,000 in the previous year. It is a great pleasure for every member of this government to recognise that later this year we will welcome to Australia the 100,000th humanitarian arrival to Australia in just under 10 years. So much for all the talk about this being a government that is not willing to welcome refugees and that is not willing to take humanitarian entrants.

Some time this year, the number will tick over to 100,000 people from offshore in desperate need. It is about at 95,000 now and we expect that we will in fact get there by the end of the year. You can be sure there will be some form of appropriate celebration, to which we may even consider inviting Labor senators. Perhaps it would do them a bit of good to come along, Mr President, because, as you know, Labor senators are always reluctant to acknowledge that this government has consistently welcomed refugees from offshore. This government is consistently ranked among the top three governments in the world for providing resettlement to people who desperately need it.

Our humanitarian program does in fact focus on those people who are in the greatest need. It does not focus and will not focus on those people who go outside the international system of protection and pay people smugglers or who run the gauntlet on a leaky boat. The proposal we have adopted is not unfair nor is it unprincipled; it is just plain good policy. To quote a former United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees:

quote.para: Step by step, we need to move towards more refugee resettlement and less irregular movement

answer.para: That is what the policies of this government do. They put a stop to irregular movements coming to Australia and focus on those who come in through the front door—in other words, to organised resettlement. You cannot have a structured permanent humanitarian program and run that alongside an open door policy. It just does not work because the latter undermines the former. Time and time again, that has been shown to be the case.

As I said, today is World Refugee Day. The theme for this year is courage. We do want to acknowledge the strength of character and the perseverance of refugees, and the courage they show in living a life in a refugee camp, hoping that someone will insist that the orderly system of taking refugees out of camps is adhered to. We welcome them having the courage, determination and trust to believe that people will not allow the international arrangements for resettlement to be undermined and that they will finally get a place. We are pleased to welcome those people here to Australia for a new life.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. As part of the Howard government’s latest embarrassing example of policy on the run, does the minister recall the Prime Minister announcing enhanced powers of ministerial discretion and intervention? The announcement promises that the government:

quote.para: ... will amend the Migration Act 1958 to provide an additional non-compellable power for the Minister, acting personally, allowing her to specify alternative arrangements for a person’s detention and impose conditions to apply to that person.

question.para: How will these new ministerial powers ensure that Australian citizens are not deported, like Vivian Solon was, or how will they ensure that permanent Australian residents needing urgent medical care are not locked up in Baxter’s management unit, as was Cornelia Rau? Given that this minister and her department have proven their incompetence, how can giving the minister even greater discretionary powers possibly improve the chances of people like Vivian Solon and Cornelia Rau?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I note the good spirit with which the opposition welcomes improvements to the government’s policy. The Prime Minister did announce on Friday a number of changes that we believe will improve the policy. I note that the senator describes this as policy making on the run. I for one would not like to live in a country where policies are announced at election time and find that that is all the policy change that ever happens—we do not have any new policy development until the next election. That is the basis on which the question is asked. If you have any policy development during the term of your government it is described as policy making on the run. That is not my description; that is the description of the senator opposite and it is a description that I reject.

answer.para: This government has consistently looked at ways of improving the situation of every policy but, in the case of this policy, the government has had very significant improvements over and above any of those which the Labor Party ever had.

talk.start.para: —Can you confirm your attendance at the meeting?

—I notice Senator Bolkus interjecting. Labor are working a bit of a tag-team here, such is the genius that operates on the other side. Senator Bolkus was immigration minister when they had hundreds and hundreds of children in detention. They did not have any housing projects to give women and children a better chance—none at all. They just shoved them in detention and hoped the problem would go away.

answer.para: Mr President, you can see that this government have studiously worked at maintaining strong border protection policies but, at the same time, doing whatever we can to soften the individual impact of those policies. The policies that were announced by the Prime Minister on Friday are a good indication of our continuing determination to do that. They provide the opportunity to give women and children who are taken into detention a further chance—over and above any bridging visas that they might have already had—to live in the community while their matters are resolved. That is a welcome opportunity, and I look forward to implementing that. The senator’s question then goes on to ask what this has to do with Ms Cornelia Rau or Ms Alvarez. The short answer to that is nothing. This is a quite independently developed policy.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister explain to the Senate whether these broader discretionary powers foreshadowed will be exercised by the minister herself, or will they be farmed out to the junior minister, Mr McGauran? Why is the minister being given new powers when the Howard government still has not organised itself to respond to the 21 recommendations of the Senate inquiry into ministerial discretion in migration matters tabled over a year ago on 13 May? Isn’t it the case that the whole problem of the culture in the immigration department came from the minister’s instructions in the first place, as we heard last week from Jamie the whistleblower?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —Having said that I hope I never live in a country where policy is made at election time and then never modified and improved as we go along lest it suffer the horrendous criticism from Labor of policy on the run—we are shattered at that—I hope I also never live in a country where people make policy on the basis of anonymous alleged whistleblowers. That is not the basis of good policy at all. The question asked was: will the ministerial discretion will be ‘farmed out’, I believe the expression was, to the junior minister? I make that point that the position of junior minister is an administrative arrangement, that minister has the same power as any other minister in a portfolio and the sharing of the workload amongst the portfolio, including the administrative arrangements, is quite normal. There is nothing different at all.

—My question is to Special Minister of State, Senator Abetz, the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Will the minister advise the Senate about the Howard government’s plans to encourage greater productivity in this country? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

—I thank Senator Troeth for her question. The improvements in productivity achieved over the past eight years under the Liberal-Nationals government are well documented. At the heart of this growth have been our workplace relations reforms. This growth has in turn contributed to a massive 14 per cent increase in real wages compared to a miserly one per cent under Labor. Over this period, over 1.5 million jobs have been created, but the government do recognise that more needs to be done. As an article in today’s Financial Review outlines, there is a need for further workplace relations reform to drive productivity. That is why the government have announced a new round of workplace relations reforms which, among other things, will increase workplace flexibility and drive further productivity improvements which, of course, means more jobs and higher wages.

answer.para: Senator Troeth asked if I was aware of any alternative policies. Yes, I am. I am aware of Mr Beazley’s ‘roll-back but only by any other name’ policy for our workplace relations reforms or, as some would more accurately describe it, Mr Beazley’s roll over to the unions. It is a policy that is nothing more than a blind parity of the union leadership and it is made by an opposition which grows more ridiculous and more misleading by the day. It is so ridiculous, in fact, that the union leadership are threatening militant strike action over reforms that we have not even finalised. They will do whatever it takes, according to Ms Burrows.

We saw the TWU protesting in Sydney. There are misleading and false ads running on TV. The unions are planning massive stop-work strikes. What are they protesting about? It reminds me of the first Howard budget. There was Mr Beazley addressing unions on the lawns of Parliament House. There was Senator Lundy with her beloved CFMEU. The protestors stormed Parliament House, breaking down the doors, rampaging through the gift shop and attacking innocent people all before our first budget was delivered. You have to ask: for what purpose? The budget came and went. Australians have enjoyed increased wealth ever since. For Labor and the union leaders, it is always protest first, investigate later.

We now fast forward to 2005. Who should be addressing a union function next week? Labor’s Craig Johnston—the man who negotiates by saying, ‘Pay up or we’ll smash your machinery.’ His topic is ‘Why bad laws are meant to be broken’. I am sure all those opposite will be there on 4 July at the John Curtin Hotel. That is the Labor Party of the 21st century—baseball bat in one hand, loudhailer in the other. Labor cannot even reform their own party’s internal structures, and I note the exemplary presence of Senators Conroy and Carr in that regard. How can they be expected to reform the Australian economy when they cannot even reform their own party? Only one side of the parliament has the courage and vision to continue the reform process that provides real benefits for Australian workers and businesses, and that is this side of the parliament.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. I refer the minister to the Prime Minister’s admission of a comprehensive policy failure in immigration by this government. I refer the minister to the following quote from the statement made by the Prime Minister last week:

quote.para: The Act would be amended to state that ‘the Parliament affirms as a principle that a minor child shall only be detained as a measure of last resort’.

question.para: Isn’t it the case that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report into children and immigration, tabled well over a year ago, recommended changes in the way children are detained? Why then did the government’s response say:

quote.para: The government rejects the major findings and recommendations contained in this report.

question.para: Didn’t this government’s arrogance towards yet another independent report result in the unnecessary detention of Bonnie Yu and Naomi Leong for the first three years of their lives?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I am not going to go into the cases of specific children because that invites a recitation of the whole family’s history, which is not very helpful. I recognise the point the Senator makes. I take it that what she is offering now is a sort of begrudging acceptance that the announcements made by the Prime Minister on Friday should in fact be welcomed by her party. They are certainly welcomed by people on this side of the parliament. You may have a complaint, Senator. You may wish to say this is too late, but you certainly cannot say it is too little. The fact that it has been done is something I would hope that all members of parliament would be pleased with.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the minister aware of recommendation 2 of the HREOC report, which stated:

quote.para: There should be a presumption against the detention of children for immigration purposes.

question.para: Why did the Howard government reject this recommendation in 2004? Why does it accept the very same recommendation now? If the Howard government knew that keeping children in detention was a problem in 2002, why did it take the government three years to reconcile itself to a morally defensible policy?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I note that the senator describes as a morally indefensible policy one that her party had and never changed. For the entire time that I was in opposition, the policy of detaining children was one that Labor adopted. As I pointed out, they never built residential housing projects so that women and children could, for example, live in a more normal, street-like atmosphere. I do not know that I thank you for that acknowledgment, Senator; I just point out the difference in what you might have said earlier as opposed to what you say now. The Prime Minister’s announcement on Friday was very clear. I would take it that it is one that you would welcome. We should all be happy with that.

—My question is also to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. I refer the minister to concerns about the treatment of Falun Gong practitioners in China by Chinese government officials and the fact that a number of Falun Gong practitioners have sought protection from Australia. Do the minister and her department believe that ordinary Falun Gong practitioners are not at significant risk of detention and torture if they are returned to China?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for the question. In essence, this question has been asked in different ways but it has been answered many times. Each protection visa application is treated on its individual merits. There are not countrywide assumptions or, for that matter, individual assumptions. As an example, I indicate that someone may claim to be a Falun Gong practitioner but, in their interview either with the department or the RRT, they may be at a loss to explain much about how it works or what their commitment is. So every case has to be treated on its merits. Every case has to be treated on the individual circumstances of the person concerned. And that is what happens.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Can the minister indicate when the department or she, in considering ministerial intervention requests on their merits, give consideration to reports such as those by the United Nations special rapporteurs on arbitrary detention and torture in China? When these individual decisions are made on their merits, can the minister assure parliament that no-one will be deported who has a valid reason to fear the types of torture detailed in reports such as those put out by the United Nations and by the US Department of State?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —As I said, each case is considered on its merits. A wide range of information is taken into account, including a variety of reports. I give you the assurance that nobody who has a valid reason for fearing persecution will ever be deported. If I can rephrase the question to make sure there is no ambiguity—and you can explain to me later if you are unhappy with this—it is my view that no-one is removed from Australia who has a proper protection claim.

—My question is to Senator Abetz representing the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and the Minister for Workplace Participation. Is the minister aware that, according to the government’s own research, up to three out of every four jobless parents have less than year 10 schooling? In the face of this overwhelming evidence of the need to build the skills base of parents who receive welfare, why is it that, under the Howard government’s confused Welfare to Work scheme, 600,000 parents on parenting payments have to fight with 65,000 mature age unemployed for just 12,300 vocational training places?

—I thank Senator Wong for her question, which was in fact on notice because she issued a press release indicating that in the last week of parliament Labor would be prosecuting this case. I indicate to Senator Wong that it is not the last week of parliament; it is, in fact, just one week of parliament and there will be a lot more weeks after August. We were told in that press release that Labor would highlight the Howard government’s so-called Welfare to Work difficulties. Senator Wong then quoted, in that press release, from the Melbourne Institute. The Melbourne Institute had this to say about education—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The point of order goes to relevance. The minister says he actually knew the question was coming, so he ought to be able to make a better fist of providing an answer. I ask you to urge him to answer the question.
—There is no point of order, and you know that.

—The Labor Party are struggling on this one. This was going to be their dynamic hit, and even the questions committee agreed that it should only be the third or fourth question down the rankings. But, as I was saying, the Melbourne Institute report that Senator Wong quoted in her press release in fact says this:

quote.para: The budget also proposes to spend additional money on services such as education and training programs et cetera.

answer.para: It just goes to show that the Melbourne Institute have identified that the government have identified the need for further education to assist in work force participation. Whilst we are on the Melbourne Institute analysis: it was of course a very difficult analysis for them to conduct because they had to make a lot of assumptions as to what Labor’s policy would be, given the huge Labor vacuum in this area. They started off by saying:

quote.para: This year’s budget of the Commonwealth government was clearly aimed at improving Australia’s labour force participation.

answer.para: Their very last sentence was:

quote.para: For the working age population overall, a moderate positive effect on employment is to be expected from the last budget.

answer.para: In between the opening and concluding statements, there is a lot of material which shows that the government have a well-rounded policy, dealing with the needs of education, the needs of training and the needs of incentives to encourage people into work.

The stark thing in the Melbourne Institute’s analysis was that they had to make all these assumptions about what Labor’s policy might be. Senator Wong, as the relevant shadow minister, comes into this chamber asserting certain things about our policy. It may be beneficial for her in her supplementary question—I am sure there is already a prewritten supplementary—to consider what the Labor Party policy is in this very important area of moving people off welfare into work.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the minister did not understand the primary question. The government’s own research shows that three-quarters of parents without jobs have year 10 education. There are 600,000 parenting payment recipients and 65,000 mature age unemployed. Can the minister explain why only 12,300 places are offered in the budget? Minister, doesn’t the absence of sufficient training places simply show that the core of the government’s Welfare to Work policy is nothing more than a cut in the incomes of some of Australia’s most vulnerable families? Why does the Howard government have such disdain for investing in the skills of Australians?

—I would invite Senator Wong to read the Hansard, because those watching would have seen Senator Wong discussing with Senator O’Brien matters other than listening to the answer I was giving. If she wants to engage in that sort of chitchat, that is up to her but then she should not have the audacity to get on her feet and assert that I have not answered the question.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The question was specifically about the training places offered to parents in the budget. The minister has not addressed that once, either in answer to the primary question or the supplementary question. I ask you to draw him to the question. My point of order is on the basis of relevance.
—Senator Abetz, I remind you of the question.
—If she had listened she would have heard me quote no lesser authority than the Melbourne Institute analysis which said:

quote.para: The budget also proposes to spend additional money on services—

talk.start.para: —If she were interested in the answer she would not be interjecting. It says:

quote.para: ... money on services such as education and training programs.

answer.para: The very point Senator Wong asked about is what I addressed immediately but because she was too busy talking to Senator O’Brien she did not catch on. That is her fault, not mine.

talk.start.para: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President’s Gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the national assembly of Papua New Guinea led by the Hon. Ian Ling-Stuckey MP. On behalf of all senators, I wish you a warm welcome to Australia and, in particular, to the Senate.

—My question is to Senator Patterson representing the Minister for Health and Ageing. Minister, has Australia entered into an agreement called the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of New Zealand for the Establishment of a Joint Scheme for the Regulation of Therapeutic Products, known as the JTA? When will this agreement come into effect? What was the public consultation process prior to Australia entering into the commitment? Is this the first step in the process of creating the trans-Tasman joint agency, and is it your government’s intention to shut down the TGA and replace it with an offshore corporation?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator PATTERSON

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Harris for the question. The Australian and New Zealand health ministers signed an agreement to establish a joint regulatory agency for therapeutic products in December 2003. The joint agency will regulate medicines, including complementary medicines, and medical devices available in Australia and New Zealand and is expected to come into force—I think that is one of the questions you asked—in July 2006. That will be subject to the passage of legislation and ratification of the treaty. You asked about consultation. Significant consultation has occurred and will occur with stakeholders, including consumers in Australia and New Zealand, on the implementing legislation once it is drafted. Once this legislation is passed by the parliaments of both countries, the treaty will come into force and a new joint regulatory scheme will begin.

answer.para: A joint agency web site has been established to ensure that all stakeholders have access to information about the project. It will be used to keep stakeholders informed of current and past developments towards the establishment of a joint agency and includes progress reports, discussion documents, media releases and frequently asked questions. The joint agency web site is www.jta.project.com.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in setting up the JTA is it your government’s intention to have the TTJA run by a chairman, a managing director, two people with regulating experience and one with commercial experience? Will this agency create a corporate partnership between the regulator and the transnational pharmaceutical corporations? Will this agency remove the decision-making authority a further step away from the Australian and New Zealand electors? Finally, will your government guarantee that no natural product or therapy will be banned or withdrawn as a result of Codex?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator PATTERSON

talk.start.para: —I do not have any details on the structure of the trans-Tasman joint agency. If there are any details that are available but not available on the web site, I will get those and present them to the Senate. Senator Harris refers to the Codex. This is the Codex Alimentarius Commission, which was established in 1963 by two United Nations organisations, the Food and Agriculture Organisation and WHO. Its main purpose is to protect consumer health and to ensure fair practices in international food trade through the development of food standards and guidelines. Codex standards and guidelines are developed by committees of the commission which are open to all member countries, including Australia. The Codex committee on nutrition and foods for special dietary uses has developed draft guidelines for vitamin and mineral food supplements. The draft Codex guidelines for vitamin and mineral food supplements specifically state that they apply in countries where vitamin and mineral supplements are regulated as foods. As these types of products are regulated as medicines in Australia, they will not be affected by the proposed Codex guidelines. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Abetz representing the Minister for Workforce Participation. Can the minister confirm that there is no guarantee that participants get any training out of the Work for the Dole scheme? Is the minister satisfied with Work for the Dole results showing that fewer than one in three participants gets a job within three months of completing the program, making it the worst-performing Howard government program? What action will be taken by the government to make Work for the Dole more effective by ensuring that participants get job training they need to get off the dole?

—I could not have hoped for a better question from my own side, because Work for the Dole is one of the most publicly supported programs of the Howard government. The Labor Party have always been against Work for the Dole but poll after poll has indicated well in excess of 80 per cent and up to 90 per cent community support for Work for the Dole. You and I have had the privilege, Mr President, of launching a number of Work for the Dole programs in Tasmania and then six months later going to the graduation. If there is one criticism of Work for the Dole by participants, it is that it does not go for long enough. Work for the Dole does provide training and, what is more important, it does support people in developing work habits. During 2004-05 the government is providing $178 million to enable an expected 85,000 unemployed people to gain valuable work experience.

answer.para: The Work for the Dole program aims to develop the work habits of participants and involve them in activities that are of value to the local community. Since 1997, when we introduced the scheme, more than 24,800 Work for the Dole activities have been approved, resulting in over 390,000 commencements. During 2003-04 there were over 74,000 commencements in Work for the Dole, up 16 per cent on the previous year. This is in an improved labour market, demonstrating the success of the active participation model in connecting the unemployed to employment services. Of those job seekers who exited Work for the Dole in the year ending June 2004, almost 40 per cent were either employed or in education or training three months after leaving the program.

They are the sorts of results that we as a government are pleased with. Can they be improved? Yes, but what would be the alternative under Labor? No Work for the Dole scheme whatsoever, and as a result the unemployed would not have this hand-up into employment that we have been offering. Labor is always satisfied with giving handouts. We say that is not good enough. That is why we have Welfare to Work programs, that is why we have Work for the Dole: because we are anxious to get every possible Australian into employment.

The Work for the Dole program enjoys—and here I have it from my colleague Minister Dutton in the notes he has provided—positive feedback from participants with 85 to 90 per cent of survey respondents indicating that they are satisfied with the response. So here we have again the Labor Party seeking to represent about 10 to 15 per cent, which is about the same percentage that are in trade unions at the moment. They always seem to be at the beck and call of those that represent about 10 or 15 per cent of the community—the extreme element in the union movement—as opposed to that element which has the overwhelming support of the Australian community. We do not apologise for having a scheme that is supported by 90 per cent of Australians and, more importantly—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator George Campbell, you know shouting is disorderly. There is no need to shout at the minister.
—We make no apology for supporting a scheme that has the support of 90 per cent of the Australian people and, what is more, 90 per cent support of participants.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that the numbers of very long-term unemployed have increased by 60 per cent over the past five years? Is it not the case that this is a direct result of the Howard government’s failure to invest in the skills of struggling job seekers? Why is the Howard government’s only answer for these very long-term unemployed simply to provide more Work for the Dole places for these people with no guarantee at all of training?

—As I would have thought most people in Australia know, the unemployment rate has fallen dramatically under this government because of our policies. That has also meant increased job opportunities for the long-term unemployed. We make no apology for saying that Work for the Dole has been deemed a success by the people of Australia and by the participants. If the Labor Party want to continue to be the party of naysayers, the obstructionists who want to find fault with everything they can, I advise them that that has been a spectacularly failing recipe over the past eight years and I suggest they come up with positive counterproposals to ours before they criticise those policies that have 90 per cent support not only in the community at large but, more importantly, from the participants themselves.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, Senator Ian Macdonald, in his capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Ian Campbell. Minister, I am sorry to have jumped this on you but I am sure you are properly briefed. Will the minister update the Senate on Australia’s efforts to prevent a resumption of commercial whaling.
—When the senators on my left have come to order we will get an answer from the minister.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation
talker.name: Senator IAN MACDONALD

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Tchen for a most insightful question, one of those which we have come to accept readily from Senator Tchen. Senator Tchen also highlights an issue of very great significance to the Australian government and indeed to every other world nation that has an interest in and a passion for marine conservation. The fact that I am answering this question rather than Senator Campbell, the environment minister, quite clearly demonstrates the high-level effort that the Australian government has put into this whaling issue. In fact, it confirms the Howard government’s reputation as the most pro-conservation government that this country has ever known.

answer.para: Australia seeks nothing less than a permanent international ban on commercial harvesting of whales, dolphins and porpoises. Senator Campbell, as we all know, is currently at the IWC, the International Whaling Commission, in Korea where he will lead the effort opposing Japan’s proposed expanded scientific whaling program in the Southern Ocean. He will also oppose the adoption of a revised management scheme which could lead to the resumption of commercial whaling. The Howard government has been very active in the fight against commercial whaling. Our Prime Minister has spoken and written to the Japanese Prime Minister, letting the Japanese know that Australia is strongly opposed to whaling at the highest level. Minister Downer has written to many counterparts. Senator Campbell has written to pro-conservation IWC members, as well as all other IWC members, indicating the very strong feeling Australia has towards whale conservation.

Senator Campbell has recently concluded a seven-day trip to 11 countries, from one end of this globe to the other, drumming up support against the commercial whaling proposal by Japan. That effort, as anyone who has ever done those things knows, demonstrates Senator Campbell’s commitment and the high energy that he has put into this fight. Our ambassador in Japan has led two demarches against the Japanese proposal to have scientific whaling. I understand that the vote at the International Whaling Commission is on a knife edge. This year there is the prospect that for the first time the pro-whaling bloc may hold a simple majority and that the adoption of the moratorium on commercial whaling may be in some danger. As a result, Australia has been working exceptionally hard with pro-conservation IWC members to encourage countries which are not members of the IWC to join and to support the bloc.

Senator Campbell is not the only one who has been working in this regard. I know Senator Gary Humphries has written to his former counterpart in Japan seeking support. Many councils we have asked have done the same. We have asked the states, too. Only Western Australia so far has indicated it is going to do so. But the member for Brand has been quite helpful. He has taken up a petition against whaling. That would be helpful if it were going to the Japanese. But unfortunately all the member for Brand, Mr Beazley, wants to do is to ask the Australian government to do something about it. He should understand that the Australian government is leading the charge against whaling. Why didn’t Mr Beazley do something useful like get his constituents to write to the Japanese about this issue? It is a great shame that Mr Beazley has been so arrogant and petty in his approach to this issue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Coonan, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. I refer to the National Farmers Federation’s statement last week that the government had only implemented half of the recommendations of the Estens inquiry into regional telecommunications and the minister’s dismissal of the NFF’s statement with the comment, ‘There’s a difference of opinion, obviously, as to what implementation means.’ Can the minister recall telling the Australian newspaper in February that she was considering auditing the implementation of the Estens inquiry to ‘give people a level of confidence’ in telecommunications services? Can the minister advise the Senate on the progress of this audit?

talker.name: Senator COONAN

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Conroy for a question about some issues that are getting a bit long in the tooth! They were from the beginning of last week, I think. I am absolutely amazed that Senator Conroy has got time to drag himself away from his battle with Senator Carr to even think about asking a question.
—He has other things on his mind.

—Very much, Senator Hill—he has other things on his mind. The news coming out of the Victorian ALP explains why Senator Conroy has not been able to concentrate on asking a question when something happens and get on top of his portfolio. I know he is very sensitive—

I was just wondering if you might want to encourage the minister to address the question. I am sure this is outside her portfolio.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There is too much noise in the chamber, on both sides. I call Senator Coonan.
—Thank you, Mr President. I will deal with the question in just a moment, but it certainly begs the question—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is not a matter for the minister to deal with the question in a moment at all; it is a requirement under standing orders that she answer the question. Quite frankly, today has set a new low for ministers failing to answer questions at all. I ask you to draw her attention to the question and ask her to answer it, as per the standing orders.

talk.start.para: —Order! I must say that the behaviour of the Senate today has been pretty ordinary, on both sides of parliament. There has been too much—
—What’s that got to do with it?
—Are you reflecting on the chair, Senator? If you are, I would ask you to leave. Senator Coonan, continue on the question.
—Thank you, Mr President. I was just putting in context—

—Mr President, I ask you to rule on the point of order about relevance. I understand that you wanted to speak to other senators about unruly behaviour—I accept that is your role—but I ask you to draw the minister’s attention to the question and ask her to be relevant and answer the question.
—I ask the minister to return to the question.

—As I was saying, Mr President, I was just putting the question in context and referring to the fact that this happened, I think, early last week. It has taken Senator Conroy quite some time to get on top of an important issue in his portfolio. That does beg the question that, while Senator Conroy and Senator Carr are ripping each other apart, trying to destroy each other’s faction, neither of them is looking after communications or the arts.

answer.para: The comments made by the National Farmers Federation are, of course, a matter of opinion for the federation, but I just remind them that they appear to be incorrect as to the number of recommendations arising out of the Estens committee which the government has currently implemented. If Senator Conroy had been paying attention, he would know that I gave a press conference in which I said that currently some 30 recommendations had been implemented out of the 39 recommended. And in fact seven of the remaining recommendations are before the Senate in some legislation that I am sure Senator Conroy is going to be very cooperative about. We are going to have a very good debate, because they relate to issues to do with a future presence of Telstra, regular reviews and ways to ensure that services for rural and regional Australia, which this government regards as very important, are up to scratch now and will continue to be so going forward.

I also made the point in the press conference, which was early last week and which completely escaped the attention of Senators Conroy and Carr, who are busy tearing each other apart, that another three quite minor recommendations will be implemented in the course of the next three weeks or so. So it is not correct to say that the recommendations—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I specifically asked a question about the promise of the minister to implement an audit. I was just wondering if at any stage she was going to address the issue of the question, which was what the result of the audit was.

—I have said and previous presidents have said that we cannot direct a minister on how to answer a question, but I remind the minister that she has over a minute left to answer the question—and she may be getting to the things that you are concerned about.

—I doubt whether I could get to the matters that concern Senator Conroy, because he is entirely engaged in factional fights in Victoria. He is not at all interested in communications and cannot even ask a question at the time when an issue arises. I have in fact dealt very directly with the question. Senator Conroy, I distinctly remember, started the question by asking whether I had taken account of some comments by the National Farmers Federation. That is precisely what I addressed when I said that this government have implemented 30 of the 39 recommendations. And we will implement all of the recommendations prior to deciding whether to proceed with the full sale of Telstra.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It has obviously escaped the minister’s attention that she answered two questions from me last week and five in total on the issue. Is the government’s arrogant rejection of any independent scrutiny or third party input confirmation of the words of Senator elect Barnaby Joyce:

quote.para: Coonan has the ministerial jet, she is on the public purse, and she wants my vote on Telstra—I don’t want anything from her—and yet here she is between sessions at the opera and her beloved French restaurants telling me to drop everything to rush to see her. The arrogance is breathtaking.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Mr President. It is my very favourite question because Senator Conroy keeps repeating it as he cannot get on top of this portfolio. He has no idea what the real issues are. The public deserve better from the ALP.

—My question is to the Minister for Defence. Was the government aware that the US used 30 napalm type firebombs in its attack on Iraq codenamed MK77? Can the government confirm that the use of these weapons breaches the 1980 convention on certain conventional weapons? What representation did you as defence minister make to the United States about the use of such weapons or did you not even bother to ask—or were you lied to as Britain was?

—I am confident that our alliance partner the United States, which has led the coalition forces in Iraq, would comply with its international obligations. In fact, I am confident that it would exceed its obligations under the international conventions, because its basic values are ones of a humanitarian response and requirement to achieve the military objectives in the best possible way.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would be obliged if the minister would confirm his knowledge on this issue, but would he also advise whether he will be encouraging the United States to ratify the convention prohibiting the use of napalm-like bombs? Could he also find out how many Iraqis were injured or killed by these weapons?

—As I said, a military objective had to be achieved. We supported that military objective. The pledge not only of the United States but of other coalition members has been to do that in the most humanitarian way. By and large, with the use of precision munitions and in other ways, it has been achieved with fewer civilian casualties than possibly any other conflict of its size in history. That will continue to be an objective both of the United States and of this government. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talk.start.para: —On Thursday in question time Senator Stott Despoja asked me about the review of human cloning and embryo research legislation. I draw her attention to the press release issued by Ms Julie Bishop, the Minister for Ageing, on 17 June 2005 in which she announced that the Australian government has appointed a retired Federal Court judge, Justice John Lockhart AO QC, to head a committee to conduct independent reviews of Australia’s Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002 and the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002. She also outlined the membership of that committee, the terms of reference and details about the legislative review committee—their backgrounds. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

para.inline: Independent Committee to Review Human Cloning and Embryo Research Legislation

quote.para: The Australian Government has appointed retired Federal Court Judge, Justice John Lockhart AO QC, to head a committee to conduct independent reviews of Australia’s Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002 and the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002.

The committee also included Associate Professor Ian Kerridge, a clinical ethicist; Professor Barry Marshall, a specialist gastroenterologist and community advocate; Professor Loane Skene, a lawyer and ethicist; Professor Peter Schofield, a neuroscientist; and Associate Professor Pamela McCombe, a clinical neurologist.

The reviews, to be conducted concurrently, are a statutory requirement of both Acts. The reports of the reviews are to be tabled in the Australian Parliament and provided to the Council of Australian Governments by 19 December 2005.
The Australian Government has received the unanimous agreement of the State and Territory governments on the membership of the committee.
The independent reviews will consult with the Australian, State and Territory governments and a broad range of people with expertise or experience in relevant disciplines.
The committee will be supported by an independent secretariat and is expected to call for written submissions shortly.

The Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002 and the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002 were passed by the Australian Parliament in December 2002. They established a strict regulatory framework to prohibit certain unacceptable practices including human cloning, and to regulate, through the National Health and Medical Research Council, research involving excess human embryos created through assisted reproductive technology.
The reviews’ terms of reference and more information about committee members are attached.
Media contact:
Rachael Thompson (Ms Bishop) 0417 265 289
Kay McNiece (Legislation Review Committee) 0412 132 585

para.inline: Terms of Reference for the review of the Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002 and the review of the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002

quote.para: 1. The Legislation Review Committee—Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002 and the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002 is required to consider and report on the scope and operation of each of the Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002 and the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002 taking into account:
(i) the following statutory requirements:
a) developments in technology in relation to assisted reproductive technology;
b) developments in medical research and scientific research and the potential therapeutic applications of such research;
c) community standards;
d) the applicability of establishing a National Stem Cell Bank; and
(ii) the following additional matters in relation to the national legislative scheme:
a) consideration of relevant aspects of State and Territory legislation corresponding to the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002.

b) the role played by State and Territory statutory bodies that regulate assisted reproductive technology (ART) treatment as well as the role of national organisations including, but not necessarily limited to, the Fertility Society of Australia and its Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee (RTAC);

c) the effectiveness of monitoring and compliance under the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002 in particular, but also in relation to the Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002 to the extent that issues may arise in relation to the latter Act;

d) the ongoing appropriateness and effectiveness of changes to the Customs regulations to regulate the export of human embryos derived through ART and the import of viable materials derived from human embryo clones;
e) options for regulation of the import and export of human embryonic stem cells;
f) the implications of cost recovery; and
g) implications for Australian science and economic activity.

2. The Legislation Review Committee is required to consult the Commonwealth, the States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory and a broad range of persons with expertise in or experience of relevant disciplines.
3. The reports must, to the extent that it is reasonably practicable, set out the views of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories and those other persons consulted.

4. Each report must contain recommendations about amendments, if any, that should be made to the Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002 and the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002, whichever is applicable.

5. The Legislation Review Committee is required to give a written report to the Council of Australian Governments and both Houses of the Parliament on the independent review of the operation of the Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002 no later than Monday 19 December 2005. The Legislation Review Committee is required to give a written report to the Council of Australian Governments and both Houses of the Parliament on the independent review of the operation of the Research Involving Human Embryos Act 2002 as an accompanying report to the report on the review of the operation of the Prohibition of Human Cloning Act 2002.

para.inline: The Honourable John Lockhart AO, QC (NSW) CHAIR

quote.para: The Honourable John Lockhart is a highly regarded member of the international legal community. He was a Justice of the Federal Court of Australia from 1978 until 1999. He has been a member of the Appellate Body of the World Trade Organization, Geneva, Switzerland since 2002 and was appointed as the Deputy Chair of the International Legal Services Advisory Council in 1994. Mr Lockhart has highly relevant experience in chairing high level committees that deliberate on contentious issues.

Professor Kerridge is a highly regarded clinical ethicist and specialist haematologist. He is the Director of the Centre for Value, Ethics & Law in Medicine at the University of Sydney; lecturer in clinical ethics with the Clinical Unit in Ethics and Health Law at the University of Newcastle. Professor Kerridge has highly relevant skills and expertise demonstrated through his work and publications in the fields of health ethics.

Professor Marshall is a highly awarded scientist of international renown who is also a successful community advocate both in Australia and overseas. He is a specialist gastroenterologist who is noted for his discovery of the link between the bacteria helicobactor pylori and gastric ulcers. He is Research Professor of Microbiology at the University of Western Australia and would also bring generalist scientific expertise in addition to his abilities in community representation.

Professor Skene is a renowned lawyer, ethicist and academic. She is Pro Vice-Chancellor, Professor of Law in the Law Faculty and an Adjunct Professor of Law in the Faculty of Medicine, Dentistry and Health Sciences at the University of Melbourne. Professor Skene has highly relevant skills and expertise demonstrated through her work and publications in the fields of health law and ethics.

Professor Schofield is a renowned neuroscientist. He is Executive Director and Chief Executive Officer of the Prince of Wales Medical Research Institute, Senior Principal Research Fellow at the Garvan Institute of Medical Research and Conjoint Professor at the Faculty of Science and Faculty of Medicine at the University of New South Wales. Professor Schofield’s skills and expertise are in a highly relevant scientific discipline to the review subject matter.

Associate Professor McCombe is a Consultant Neurologist and a Visiting Medical Officer at the Royal Brisbane Hospital and holds the position of Associate Professor, Department of Medicine at the University of Queensland. She is Chair of the Wesley Research Institute Research Committee and Chair of the Scientific Program Committee of the Australian Association of Neurologists.
