speech.para: The work done by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in its consideration of the Criminal Code Amendment (Trafficking in Persons Offences) Bill 2004 [2005] has been much appreciated. I want to acknowledge the work of committee members and the chair, Senator Payne, who cannot be here this evening. The government have carefully considered the recommendations made by the Senate committee. We have taken on board a number of those recommendations, and in addressing government amendments (1) to (25) it is best if I deal with each recommendation in turn to place on record the government’s response.

Certainly in relation to recommendation 1, the government supports the Senate committee’s recommendation that proposed sections 271.2 and 271.5 of the bill should be amended to clarify that the prosecution is not required to prove the consent of victims. The government, however, does not support recommendation 2, that proposed sections 271.2(1) and 271.5(1) be amended to include in the trafficking offences an element of a purpose of exploitation. The offences should not be limited to where both a means of trafficking is used and the victim is exploited. The conduct of using force or threats against the victim as a means of trafficking that victim into Australia is criminal, even when there is no proof of exploitation. For that reason, the government does not support that recommendation.

The government believes that it has addressed recommendation 3 of the Senate committee report by including new international and domestic trafficking offences that do not specify a means of trafficking but require the perpetrator to be reckless as to whether the victim will be exploited. These offences will capture trafficking activity regardless of whether threats, force, deception or any other means are used that are specifically listed in article 3(a) of the United Nations Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons Especially Women and Children, supplementing the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organised Crime. There will be no doubt that the trafficking and domestic trafficking offences will not only apply but also go beyond the means of trafficking listed in the protocol.

Recommendation 4 of the committee report is supported by the government. I point to the fact that the deceptive recruiting for sexual services offence in the bill has been expanded so that it will be an offence to intentionally induce a person to enter into an engagement to provide sexual services by deceiving them about the nature of the sexual services they will have to provide. If there is a debt owed by the victim in connection with the engagement to provide sexual services it will also be an offence for the perpetrator to deceive the victim about the quantum or existence of that debt.

The government supports recommendation 5 of the Senate committee report, so trafficking offences by means of deception have been expanded to include all the types of deception that are in the deceptive recruiting for sexual services offence. The government does not, however, support recommendation 6, which seeks to adopt the definitions of trafficking in persons and exploitation contained in the trafficking protocol. The bill comprehensively criminalises trafficking activity and complies with the protocol. The provisions have been drafted to ensure that the requirements in the trafficking protocol are met by domestic legislation while complying with and recognising the limits of Commonwealth constitutional power.

Recommendation 7 of the committee report has been partially accepted so that the definition of sexual services that applies to the trafficking in children and domestic trafficking in children offences includes non-commercial sexual services. This means that children will be better protected, as a child will not be able to be trafficked where that child will be used to provide sexual services, regardless of whether or not the services are for a commercial purpose. However, an extension of the definition in the case of trafficking in adults would inadvertently criminalise certain activities which, while involving an element of deception which is socially unacceptable, should not be subject to the same criminal sanctions. For example, where a person induces another person to come to Australia with an offer of work or accommodation but deceives that other person about the fact that the real intention is to commence a sexual relationship, that might be something which is purely a personal matter. Someone who wants to form a relationship with someone as an adult might try to get them to come to Australia to work as a means of impressing upon them that a relationship with them would be no bad thing to enter into. There might be absolutely no relationship whatsoever to any commercial exploitation in that.

The government has looked at whether the definition of exploitation in the bill should be amended to include an express reference to servile marriages, with reference to recommendation 8. It would be a significant step to create offences that deal with servile marriages and it is important that we carefully consider the type of conduct that should be captured, taking into account social and cultural issues, before we enact new offences. The issue of servile marriages is of concern to the government, and this is a matter my department will pursue further to ensure that the full range of conduct that should be covered by Commonwealth law is covered. In the meantime, the trafficking offences will apply if force or threats are used against a person who is trafficked for the purpose of a servile marriage. Some situations may also be covered by slavery offences already in the Criminal Code.

The government supports recommendation 9 of the Senate committee report. The offence of debt bondage prevents traffickers from using unfair debt contracts and other similar arrangements to force victims into providing sexual services or other labour to pay off large debts. The definition of debt bondage will be expanded to include unfair debt contracts where the up-front contract amount is manifestly excessive. This will catch traffickers who invent or grossly inflate debts owed to them by their victims.

The government also supports recommendation 10 that division 270 of the Criminal Code should have the same definition of ‘deceive’ that the bill includes in proposed division 271. Recommendation 13 of the Senate report has been incorporated into the bill to make it clear that the protective regime for child witnesses and complainants in part IAD of the Crimes Act 1914 will apply to proceedings for trafficking offences.

Recommendations 11 and 12 of the Senate committee report deal with consultation by the government on the bill, and this is a point which Senator Ludwig has raised. The consultation that prefaced the introduction of the bill included a broad range of government and non-government stakeholders in the government’s broader trafficking in persons package. In the general area of trafficking in persons, I have worked closely with my state and territory counterparts through the Australasian Police Ministers Council, which I mentioned earlier. In October 2003, the Australian Crime Commissioners Forum adopted proposals for a national plan of action to combat trafficking in women for the purposes of sexual servitude. The National Policing Strategy to Combat Trafficking in Women for Sexual Servitude 2004-06 was endorsed by the APMC in July 2004.

Apart from that work with stakeholders in the state and territory jurisdictions, the department, during the preparation of the bill, has also consulted extensively with a number of key stakeholders, including the Australian Federal Police, the Office for Women, the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations. In fact, I issued a press release about this bill on 31 August last year, and the exposure draft was prominently placed on the department’s web site, with an invitation to comment on the bill by 18 October last year. Those submissions were used in finalising the content of the bill, particularly the debt bondage offence.

There has been extensive consultation in relation to this bill and we believe that we have reached a point where we can put this next measure in place. There will be ongoing work in dealing with sex trafficking, but I want to place on record the work that has been done in consultation across the board in relation to this bill. The amendments cover a range of issues that were raised by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee and they certainly go a long way to addressing those concerns. I believe that this will toughen up our legislation in relation to sex trafficking. I have covered in detail the government’s reaction to those recommendations. I commend the amendments to the committee.

talk.start.para: —The debate on the Criminal Code Amendment (Trafficking in Persons Offences) Bill 2004 [2005] has been a little truncated. My original contribution was some time ago. Due to the way the program has progressed, we dealt with the remainder of the second reading debate, which we have completed. We now have the committee stage of the bill in which we are considering the amendments that the government has moved. Also, there is one amendment that Labor is pursuing.

speech.para: It is worth at least taking a short while to address what this bill effectively does. The bill improves the existing federal regime for offences of trafficking in persons. It criminalises nearly all, if not all, aspects of trafficking in persons. The important part is that it fulfils Australia’s legislative obligations under a number of treaties, including the United Nations Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons Especially Women and Children, supplementing the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organised Crime—the trafficking protocol, as it is referred to in short. What this bill will effectively bring about is a substantive change to the law in Australia as to how we deal with this heinous crime. It is certainly overdue.

Labor has supported the general thrust of this legislation and has maintained a significant interest in ensuring that this bill passes in a form that ensures that it is effective in its operation and covers the relevant areas of criminality that it should. To that end, Labor referred the bill to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. Labor had a number of concerns with this bill when it was first introduced. One of those concerns goes to some of the detail, which I will take a little while to go through shortly.

Notwithstanding what the minister may have said about consultation, one of the major areas that we identified in the hearings, and later in the committee report, was that some major agencies such as HREOC had not been effectively consulted on how this bill would operate. Labor, along with the Democrats, should and will take credit for raising the issue of consultation during the committee reporting period, and subsequently with various bodies, to ensure not only that the bill was left on the internet as an exposure draft but also that parties with an interest in this bill had an opportunity to make submissions to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee and to knock on the minister’s door to argue their various issues and cases.

With good intentions, the government has substantively picked up many of the recommendations made by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. Let me come to that issue in brief. The Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee made a number of recommendations to which I will take the Senate shortly. This highlights one of the most important processes that this parliament has, which got an airing in the Senate during question time today: the usefulness of committee reports and the processes that they go through. This bill and the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee highlight one of the most important processes that can occur. Not only did the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee engage in the process but the submitters also made substantive submissions which effectively brought about change to this bill for the better, in Labor’s view. In addition to that, the government took those amendments on board and picked them up because it saw the merit in them. Substantive amendments to the bill were brought down to improve its overall effectiveness.

We can thank the government for listening to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. It also goes to the ability of the chair, Senator Payne, who ensured that the process was followed properly and that the bill was examined in a thorough way. The committee has produced an excellent report that ensures that the relevant issues have been dealt with.

Going to some of the particular detail—and perhaps we can deal with it in a brief synopsis—the government amendments effectively arise out of the committee process. Recommendation 1 referred to the removal of references to consent in clauses 271.2(1) and 271.5(1), and was accepted. Recommendation 2 was that an element of a purpose of exploitation be included in clauses 271.2 and 271.5. Recommendation 3 was that any doubt be removed that clauses 271.2 and 271.5 contain each means of trafficking listed in the definition of ‘trafficking in persons’ contained in article 3(a) of the UN Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons Especially Women and Children, supplementing the United Nations convention against Organised Crime. Recommendation 4 referred to the inclusion in clause 271.7 of deception about the quantum of any debt or purported debt owed or which will be owed by the person.

Recommendation 5 referred to the inclusion of various express references to deception in clauses 271.2(2) and 271.5(2). Recommendation 6, although partially adopted, referred to the inclusion of an element of a purpose of exploitation, which was really picked up in recommendation 2. Recommendation 7, which was partially adopted, referred to the inclusion of non-commercial exploitation of children. Recommendation 9 referred to the inclusion of the offence of debt bondage. Recommendation 10 referred to the inclusion of the definition of deception in proposed division 271. Recommendation 13 referred to the extension of part IAD of the Crimes Act 1914 to offences against proposed division 271.

That is a brief synopsis. They are important changes that the government has now introduced as amendments to this bill to improve the overall effectiveness and operation of this bill. Given the bill’s main aim, the amendments can only be supported by Labor because they will provide a better outcome for the law enforcement agencies to conduct investigations and prosecute persons who offend against this legislation when it is enacted.

However, the government chose to reject a number of the recommendations made by the committee. Labor listened to what the government said about those recommendations, and we can say that recommendation 6 was partially rejected. It was about the adoption of the definitions of ‘exploitation’ and ‘trafficking in persons’ contained in the UN Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons Especially Women and Children. Labor accepted the advice of the Attorney-General’s Department that it is better to use terms appropriate to the Australian legal system, which have already been defined in both the parliament and the courts. Of course, one of the issues was whether we should not simply adopt the definition as per the protocol. The Attorney-General’s Department persuasively argued that it would be a far better position to adopt that which is more familiar to our Australian legal system, and Labor have accepted that position.

Recommendation 7, which was effectively partially rejected, relates to the inclusion of non-commercial exploitation of adults. Labor note the government’s claim that, while this may be immoral, it may not be desirable to make this conduct illegal without further and detailed investigation into the consequences of doing so. Given the safeguards that apply where children are concerned that are currently proposed in this bill, Labor reserve the right to investigate this matter further to determine whether this type of conduct should be made illegal—or unlawful, as the case may be—and, if so, by what methods. I think further work needs to be done in this particular area, and we will be examining this in due course to ensure that the inclusion of non-commercial exploitation of adults is examined further—but not within the confines of this bill. We do not think this issue is sufficient to prevent the passage of this bill or to support an amendment, given the nature of the current legislation.

Recommendation 8 was totally rejected. It dealt with the inclusion of servile marriages in the bill. Labor accepts that this measure required further investigation, as it may affect or involve amendments to the Marriage Act. Labor accepts that this recommendation is beyond the scope of this bill, but Labor similarly reserves the right to pursue the matter further in a broader way that may encompass the Marriage Act. I will not foreshadow anything today, but it is an issue that Labor believes should be examined further. It is an important area, and it certainly has the potential to affect many people.

Recommendations 11 and 12 deal with community consultation. I referred to that more broadly in the opening part. They also included a referral to the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee. Labor accepts that it has done the job of community consultation for the government to ensure a good outcome, using the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee—although I note, if I may, that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee says to those government agencies that think the committee is part of the consultative process: it is not. I am certain that Senator Payne would associate herself with that remark, but I will check that and if it is not the case I will correct the record. My understanding is that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee does examine the legislation, make recommendations and hear submissions and the like. It does not perform community consultation on behalf of the government. That is something for government to do and to demonstrate to the committee how it has gone about consulting both internally and externally with its own agencies and other agencies.

In addition, the government adopted measures that did not arise out of the committee process that have Labor’s support. They are new offences similar to existing trafficking offences but cover circumstances where the trafficking involves the exit of people out of Australia. Labor supports that matter. In addition, there are increases in the maximum sentencing for trafficking in children from 20 to 25 years, which bring them into line with slavery offences. They are issues, particularly the last one, that really bring the bill into line with the other legislation in this area and deserve support. The first one, dealing with exiting, ensures that Australia is not used as a place for trafficking, not only into but also out of Australia. For all the reasons why the bill is a sensible advancement for the safety and protection of women and, especially, children, it is also sensible to support that amendment. There is one amendment that Labor will be progressing, but I will deal with that later in this committee stage.

talk.start.para: —Senator Ludwig has gone through, in considerable detail, a precis of the recommendations and a sketch of the government’s response. There is little point in me going over that again. I will just make a couple of comments. Firstly, I would like to acknowledge and praise Senate processes that have been active here. It was very frustrating for me, as I expect it was for most government members, to wake this morning to the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald and the lead story about the vast number of parliamentary inquiries into which a lot of money is poured, which do a lot of work and which produce a lot of recommendations—seemingly none of which are taken up by government.

speech.para: Only last week I had a staffer over from Perth and we came up with the idea of looking into how far the government had gone in implementing the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs investigation into poverty, which were tabled about a year ago. It was our view that, if we could find some recommendations which had not been enacted, we could embark on that as a project. We discovered that none of the recommendations had been enacted. We were then broadening our inquiry to other parliamentary reports, only to be gazumped by a journalist from the Sydney Morning Herald who made it a much broader story.

That is a footnote but the point I am trying to make is that this is an example of a parliamentary inquiry which has received not just bipartisan but multiparty support, one which has engaged with the community, one which has taken considerable evidence from a vast array of interesting organisations and people, and one which has produced a range of recommendations, the majority of which the government has taken up. I think that those that it has not taken up are defensible—I think the government can reasonably defend its position on those recommendations it is choosing not to enact on this occasion. For example, the point the government raises about the complexity and difficult cultural issues of recommendation eight, relating to servile marriages, is an acceptable argument.

I will say no more on this other than to agree to the amendments put forward by the government. My key point, and that of the Democrats, is not so much the minutiae of the Criminal Code Amendment (Trafficking in Persons Offences) Bill 2004 [2005] and the ratification of the protocol but our ongoing concern for the care and welfare of the women concerned: those who have been discovered to be trafficked or who present themselves as such and seek care and support from the government and its authorities as they go through the processes of trying to deal with their situation—whether or not through providing information to the police. That remains a key area of concern for us, and I spoke to that in greater detail in my second reading contribution. We can and do support the amendments before us. We agree with the government that, in those areas where it disagrees with the committee’s recommendations, the points it makes are fair.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

amendment.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 7, page 4 (line 31), after “English”, insert “or the language in which the deception or inducement occurred”.
R(1A) Schedule 1, item 9, page 10 (line 6), after “English”, insert “or the language in which the deception or inducement occurred”.

speech.para: These amendments go to removing a possible unintended defence to the proposed offences against deceptive recruiting of another person to provide sexual services in section 270.7 and debt bondage under the proposed section 271.8. As it stands, the Criminal Code Amendment (Trafficking in Persons Offences) Bill 2004 [2005] specifies in the proposed section 270.7—we should come up with a different numbering system for this bill eventually, with the way we use 270.7 and the like, but I guess that is for another day—that, in determining whether or not an offence of deceptive recruiting for sexual services has taken place, the jury may treat as admissible evidence the personal circumstances of a victim, including the person’s ability to speak, write and understand English. This means, for example, that if a person from a non-English speaking background is recruited in the English language, the jury may take into account that the person was not proficient in the language and may therefore have been deceived.

Similarly, under the proposed section 271.8, there is a new offence of debt bondage. One of the circumstances a jury may consider in determining an offence under this section is whether or not the victim was proficient in English when recruited in that language—that is, the person’s proficiency in English is specifically admissible. However, in both of these sections by implication a possible unintended defence may arise where the deceptive recruiting is conducted in a language other than English. Now that the offence includes both entry into and exit from Australia, this is admittedly a belt and braces approach—but it is intended to ensure that the jury can take into consideration not only English but also languages other than English.

There are a number of examples that I could go into, but I will not take up time in the chamber. It can easily be understood that English may not be the language used by either the traffickers or the person being trafficked. They might discover that all the conversations were in a language other than English. In those types of instances, where the deceptive recruiting occurs in a language other than English, the jury may not consider the evidence as admissible, since the legislation only specifically mentions deceptive recruiting in English. It is unacceptable for that issue not to go to the jury. There is an unintended ambiguity in this bill as I understand it. I am sure that if we are wrong about that the minister will correct us in our view.

But the clear intent is to ensure that this bill covers deceptive recruiting in all languages, not merely English, and that effectively the jury can take that into consideration. This is particularly important because many of the source countries for sex trafficking are not English-speaking countries and many of the traffickers do not speak English and can be relied upon to conduct their despicable trade in languages other than English. Labor support the use of the strongest measures that are reasonably possible to combat the exploitation of women and children, so we are pleased to be able to commend what we think is a straightforward amendment to the Senate and the minister to be included within the legislation, to rule out any ambiguity that may arise. It will ensure that it is not limited to English but has a wider operation so that these matters can be dealt with.

I might add, for the benefit of the chair, that I will not be moving the next amendment, which is why I did not seek to have those co-joined—although they were about different issues. There is a view about how we might progress that, but I will not take up the Senate’s time in dealing with that. They are matters that would amend legislation outside this bill. We think we should confine ourselves to matters within this bill while we are seeking amendments.

talk.start.para: —I seek to clarify with Senator Ludwig whether, when he said he was not moving his second amendment, he meant that which appears as amendment (2) on the running sheet or amendment (1A).

—I mean amendment (2)—we have moved amendment (1) and amendment R(1A) together—which goes to the issue of victim impact statements, having looked at the issue a number of times and given that the government has moved a long way, may I say, in picking up the recommendations of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee and ensuring that there was reasonable consultation, at least post the starting of the process. It was disappointing it was not done earlier, but, having said that a number of times now, I should stop saying it; I think the government has got the point.

speech.para: The issue of the victim impact statements is a matter that Labor feel strongly about. The difficulty is that it would be progressing in legislation outside that covered in this bill. We would not be amending this legislation to bring it in; we would have to amend the Crimes Act. Perhaps I could foreshadow that, to that end, we will have a longer and harder look at it. I might also take the opportunity to go and speak to the Democrats about how we might ensure that this particular matter is not lost in the ether but progressed.

Labor feel quite strongly about the issue of victim impact statements. However, the government has indicated that it is not willing to support that particular amendment, and Labor are unwilling to delay the passage of this bill. We appreciate that there is a real need for it, and we intend to untie the support into the Crimes Act from this Criminal Code amendment. Although they are two related pieces of legislation, if that is the way to put it, we do not think it is appropriate given the government’s position.

If the government changed their mind, however, we could probably find a way through. But, given that they are unlikely at this late stage to change their view about opposing our considered and sensible amendment, we do not want to put it in the way of getting this legislation through because of the benefits it would otherwise provide. However, I will take the opportunity to restate Labor’s strong interest in the rights of victims of crime and foreshadow, as I said, our intention to take the issue of victim impact statements further when parliament resumes again.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ludwig for his clarification. We can and do support Labor’s amendments (1) and (1A). Those amendments are aimed at ensuring that prosecutions for trafficking offences are not hampered in circumstances where an alleged trafficking victim’s first language is not English. The bill currently provides that, in determining whether an alleged victim has been deceived, the court may take into account the personal circumstances of the victim, including his or her ability to speak, write and understand English. The risk with that provision, though, is that if the defence can demonstrate that an alleged victim was mistaken because of a language difficulty then it may be harder to prove that there was any deceit on the part of the alleged trafficker. Senator Ludwig’s amendments address those circumstances where the deceptive conduct or the inducement was made in another language. For example, a Thai woman may have been deceived by traffickers who communicated to her in Thai. Senator Ludwig’s amendment ought to help to ensure that deceptive conduct is punished regardless of which language the deception occurred in. To that end, we can support the amendments.

—Both Senator Ludwig and Senator Greig have outlined the purpose of these amendments. The government agrees with that. It supports opposition amendments (1) and R(1A). I do not think there is anything I can usefully add.

speech.para: Question agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Senators Ludwig, Bartlett and Nettle to move on the next day of sitting:

item.para: That the following matters be referred to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee for inquiry and report by 8 November 2005:

item.label: (a)
item.para: the administration and operation of the Migration Act 1958, its regulations and guidelines by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, with particular reference to the processing and assessment of visa applications, migration detention and the deportation of people from Australia;

item.label: (b)
item.para: the activities and involvement of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and any other government agencies in processes surrounding the deportation of people from Australia;

item.label: (c)
item.para: the adequacy of healthcare, including mental healthcare, and other services and assistance provided to people in immigration detention;

item.label: (e)
